abstract.p: Maharaja Jai Singh I writes to the Mughal prince Dara Shukoh, acknowledging the orders received in the prince's earlier order. He confirms that he will not halt more than a couple days in Allahabad, expresses approval regarding the appointments of nobles, promises to reprimand a rebellious group in Patna, and thanks the prince for granting the district (pargana) of Niwai as part of his revenue assignment (jagir).This petition was written during the War of Succession during a period when Jai Singh I was allied with Dara Shukoh. This letter was copied in a manuscript miscellany that was acquired and likely produced in a colonial context, possibly for James Tod. It appears to be a response to the order (nishan) of Dara Shukoh to Jai Singh I dated 7 Rabiʿ al-awwal 1068, which is held in the Rajasthan State Archives. See A Descriptive List of Farmans, Manshurs and Nishans, p. 35, S.No. 226.

the eighth of Rabiʿ al-awwal of the year 1068Here, there is likely a scribal error, writing eight (hashtom) instead of twentieth (bistom), given that the document references the nineteenth of the same month.. This, that the ʿarzdasht of the humblest servant of true belief Jai Singh, who had
performed the rituals of the greetings of devotion and servitude, shall be presented to the audience of the Nawab of the Most Pure Titles,
the Ruler of the World and Conquerer of the Countries, Lord of the Universe and of Mortal Creation, Prince of the Earth and Mortals [i.e., Dara Shukoh],
[stating] that the imperial nishan of the exalted mercy of power and grace, which had been issued for the exaltation
of [your] oldest slave, cast the shadow of arrival on the date nineteen, 19, of the month Rabiʿ al-awwal in the place of RajpurThe location of this place is unclear as it is a very common placename. It was likely somewhere in the Gangetic plains between Delhi and Allahabad..
Enacting the rules of the obeisance of servitude, on the bowed head the height of honour and prosperity
was elevated. The Lord of Mortals [be] well. The command of the exalted rank, which was implemented according to the noble, eminent order,
[was] that after arriving in Allahabad, they should depart after halting no more than three or four days.
Lord of Creation [be] well. By reason that it was ordered, they will not stay
more than three or four days. And the assembly, which from among the mansabdars had been attached
to the victorious stirrup of the Nawab of Eminent Glory, the Prince of Creation, shall diligently implement the command of the exalted rank so that those men
quickly shall attain honour from attendance [on] the Son of the Lord of Mortals. From the news-writers thus
it became known that they had made the appointment of Malwa to Sujan Singh Bundela. If they keep some of the crumbs of the
of the mansabdars in his compensation, it is appropriate because he is a useful servant and has a good assembly [of troops]
and his land is near and abutting this district. In this is the necessary work of the good of the state.
And the illustrious order had been issued that the assembly [of people]This likely refers to the prince Shah Shuja and his army. that had come from Bengal to Patna
should be given appropriate admonishment [and] return from there. The Lord of the World and Creation [be] well. When [they] arrive there,

in accordance with what is ordered, it will be implemented. And from the perfection of favours and kindnesses
the command of the sublime rank produced the honour that I received the pargana Niwai in the increase of [my] jagir.
By what tongue shall thanksgiving for the boundless favours be offered standing in the assembly of the Lord?
From the court of the glory of God, I hope that attaining honourable service, contentment
will be attained in this. May he, the Divine, the Shadow of Shadows, keep that Lord of Creation, forever and perpetually among the distinguished servants of the true faith.
